content: The Act may be cited as the "Innovators to Entrepreneurs Act of 2018". The National Science Foundation Innovation Corps Program, known as I-Corps, has successfully increased the commercialization of Government-funded research by providing valuable entrepreneurial education to graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and other researchers. The I-Corps Teams program focuses on providing specific types of education and mentoring for entrepreneurs at the early stage of their ventures. The I-Corps Program provides valuable entrepreneurial education and mentoring to entrepreneurs in the early stages of their ventures. It is suggested to expand this success by offering additional training to small businesses as they advance towards commercialization. Additionally, the training should be made available to all Federal grantees and businesses willing to pay for it. The program has been successful in promoting entrepreneurship within research institutions and encouraging research commercialization. The National Science Foundation has been working on building a network of science entrepreneurs by convening stakeholders, promoting I-Corps courses, cataloguing best practices, encouraging sharing, and developing a mentor network. As the I-Corps Program grows, the focus should remain on networking and information sharing to help innovators learn from each other and stay competitive. SEC. 3. EXPANDED PARTICIPATION IN I-CORPS. Section 601(c)(2) of the American Innovation and Competitiveness Act is amended to allow Small Business Innovation Research Program grantees and other entities to participate in an I-Corps Teams course. Small Business Innovation Research Program grantees and other entities can participate in an I-Corps Teams course, with the cost covered by grants or funds from the grantor Federal agency. The Small Business Innovation Research Program grantees and other entities can participate in an I-Corps Teams course, with the cost covered by grants or funds from the grantor Federal agency. Funding can also come from the Small Business Technology Transfer Program or participating teams. SEC. 4. I-CORPS COURSE FOR COMMERCIALIZATION-READY PARTICIPANTS. The Director shall develop an I-Corps course for commercialization-ready participants, focusing on skills like attracting investors and building a brand. Stakeholder engagement may be sought, and eligible participants must have completed an I-Corps Teams course or decided to take an innovation to market. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress evaluating the I-Corps program's impact on commercializing Federally funded research, the higher education system, and regional and national economies within 2 years of the Act's enactment. SEC. 6. FUNDING. $5,000,000 authorized for fiscal years 2019 and 2020 for National Science Foundation activities. No additional funds authorized for this Act, to be carried out using available amounts.
